fields.value: Intellectual contributions meriting authorship: Survey results from the top cited authors across all science categories

dsDescriptionValue.value: These files contain the results of the survey that we published in PLOS ONE (doi: 10.1371/journal.pone.0198117)

publicationCitation.value:
Intellectual contributions meriting authorship:
Survey results from the top cited authors across all science categories

fields.value: A soon as the paper will be published, we will update the URL

files.description:
The file 2017-12-02 PLOS ONE raw consolidate.xlsx contains the raw data plus statistical data and a means to select data segments to identify trends. The first column in sheet original is the time each respondent took to complete the survey. The second column is the total score of the responses (from J to AH): almost always gives a score of 100 and almost never gives a score of 0. Column D is the mean of the scores of J to AH, column E is the standard deviation, and column F is the number of responses. Column F is the country code and column E is the country. 
Column H is the experience level and column I is the field. Column AJ is the type of institute and columns AK to BE are the consolidated science categories that we assigned to the fields mentioned in columns (I and AI) from the categories in BM to CG. The spreadsheet allows one to analyze country of origin (column F) and/or region (column G), and/or level of experience (column H) and/or consolidated field (column BG), and/or science category (column CI).
For example, to study response from Canada in the original worksheet, in the search field icon at G1, select Canada. Copy paste the entire spreadsheet starting from the first row of data at below row 5 into row 8 of the all spreadsheet. The calc worksheet and the sheet 1 contains all the summary data for Canada
files.label: 2017-12-02 PLOS One consolidate.xlsx

dataFile.description:
The file 2017-12-02 PLOS ONE raw consolidate.xlsx contains the raw data plus statistical data and a means to select data segments to identify trends. The first column in sheet original is the time each respondent took to complete the survey. The second column is the total score of the responses (from J to AH): almost always gives a score of 100 and almost never gives a score of 0. Column D is the mean of the scores of J to AH, column E is the standard deviation, and column F is the number of responses. Column F is the country code and column E is the country. 
Column H is the experience level and column I is the field. Column AJ is the type of institute and columns AK to BE are the consolidated science categories that we assigned to the fields mentioned in columns (I and AI) from the categories in BM to CG. The spreadsheet allows one to analyze country of origin (column F) and/or region (column G), and/or level of experience (column H) and/or consolidated field (column BG), and/or science category (column CI).
For example, to study response from Canada in the original worksheet, in the search field icon at G1, select Canada. Copy paste the entire spreadsheet starting from the first row of data at below row 5 into row 8 of the all spreadsheet. The calc worksheet and the sheet 1 contains all the summary data for Canada

files.description: The file 2017-12-02 PLOS ONE raw data.xlsx contains the 6562 responses in the sheet Initial.  We convert the responses Almost never, sometimes, often, usually, almost always to 0, 1, 2, 3, 4 in sheet Score and include an additional 43 responses. We also assigned the disciplines to categories.
files.label: 2017-12-02 PLOS One raw data.xlsx

We convert the responses Almost never, sometimes, often, usually, almost always to 0, 1, 2, 3, 4 in sheet Score and include an additional 43 responses.
